original: Milindapañha
analyzed: milindapañha
translated: The Questions of King Milinda

original: Meṇḍakapañha🔽Paṇāmitavagga
analyzed: meṇḍakapañha  paṇāmita vagga
translated: The Questions of Menander🔽The Chapter on the Sending Away

original: 12. Bhikkhupaṇāmitapañha
analyzed: bhikkhu paṇāmita pañha
translated: The Questions of the Monk Paṇāmita

original: “Bhante nāgasena, bhāsitampetaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: bhante nāgasena bhāsitam petam bhagavatā
translated: “Venerable Nāgasena, this was said by the Blessed One:

original: ‘akkodhano vigatakhilohamasmī’ti, puna ca tathāgato there sāriputtamoggallāne saparise🔽paṇāmesi, kiṁ nu kho, bhante nāgasena, tathāgato kupito parisaṁ paṇāmesi, udāhu tuṭṭho
analyzed: akkodhanaḥ vigata khilaḥ ham asmi iti puna ca tathāgataḥ there sāriputta moggallāne sa parise  paṇāmesi kim nu kho bhante nāgasena tathāgataḥ kupitaḥ parisam paṇāmesi udāhu tuṭṭhaḥ
translated: ‘I am without anger, without bitterness,’ and yet the Tathāgata sent away the elders Sāriputta and Moggallāna with their retinue.

original: paṇāmesi, etaṁ tāva jānāhi imaṁ nāmāti?🔽Yadi, bhante nāgasena, kupito parisaṁ paṇāmesi, tena hi tathāgatassa kodho appaṭivattito, yadi tuṭṭho paṇāmesi, tena hi avatthusmiṁ ajānantena paṇāmitā.
analyzed: paṇāmesi etam tāva jānāhi imam nāma ati  yadi bhante nāgasena kupitaḥ parisam paṇāmesi tena hi tathāgatassa kodhaḥ appaṭivattitaḥ yadi tuṭṭhaḥ paṇāmesi tena hi avatthusmim a jānantena paṇāmitā
translated: Now, venerable Nāgasena, was it out of anger that the Tathāgata sent away the assembly, or was it out of satisfaction?

original: Ayampi ubhato koṭiko pañho tavānuppatto, so tayā nibbāhitabbo”ti.
analyzed: ayam pi ubhatas koṭikaḥ pañho tava anuppatto saḥ tayā nibbāhitabbaḥ ti
translated: This is the first question, my good man, that you have to answer.”

original: “Bhāsitampetaṁ, mahārāja, bhagavatā—
analyzed: mahā rāja bhagavatā
translated: “Venerable Nāgasena, this was said by the Blessed One:

original: ‘akkodhano vigatakhilohamasmī’ti, paṇāmitā ca therā sāriputtamoggallānā saparisā, tañca pana na kopena.
analyzed: akkodhanaḥ vigata khilaḥ ham asmi iti paṇāmitā ca therā sāriputta moggallānā sa parisā tat ca pana na kopena
translated: ‘I am without anger, without bitterness,’ and yet the elders Sāriputta and Moggallāna with their retinue were sent away, and that was not out of anger.

original: Idha, mahārāja, kocideva puriso mahāpathaviyā mūle vā khāṇuke vā pāsāṇe vā kaṭhale vā visame vā bhūmibhāge khalitvā patati, api nu kho, mahārāja, mahāpathavī kupitā taṁ pātetī”ti?
analyzed: mahā rāja kaścid eva purisaḥ mahā pathaviyāḥ mūle vā khāṇuke vā pāsāṇe vā kaṭhale vā visame vā bhūmi bhāge khalitvā patati api nu khalu mahā rāja mahā pathavī kupitā tam pāta iti iti
translated: Suppose, sire, some man should fall down on the ground, on a stump, on a stone, on a clod of earth, or on uneven ground, would the great earth be angry with him because he fell down?”

original: “Na hi, bhante, natthi mahāpathaviyā kopo vā pasādo vā, anunayappaṭighavippamuttā mahāpathavī, sayameva so alaso khalitvā patito”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhante natthi mahā pathaviyā kopaḥ vā pasādaḥ vā anunaya ppaṭigha vippamuttā mahā pathavī sayam eva saḥ alasaḥ khalitvā patito ti
translated: “No, revered sir, there is no anger or favour in the great earth, the great earth is free from affection and aversion, the lazy man falls down by himself and gets up by himself.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, natthi tathāgatānaṁ kopo vā pasādo vā, anunayappaṭighavippamuttā tathāgatā arahanto sammāsambuddhā, atha kho sayaṁ kateneva te attano aparādhena paṇāmitā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja natthi tathāgatānam kopaḥ vā pasādaḥ vā anunaya ppaṭigha vippamuttāḥ tathāgatāḥ arahanto sammāsambuddhāḥ atha kho sayam katena iva te attanaḥ aparādhena paṇāmitāḥ
translated: “Even so, sire, there is no anger or favour in the Tathāgatas, the Arahants, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, the Tathāgatas are free from affection and aversion, but they are banished because of their own offence.

original: Idha pana, mahārāja, mahāsamuddo na matena kuṇapena saṁvasati, yaṁ hoti mahāsamudde mataṁ kuṇapaṁ, taṁ khippameva nicchubhati thalaṁ ussāreti.
analyzed: idha pana mahā rāja mahā samuddaḥ na matena kuṇapena savasati yam hoti mahā samudde matam kuṇapa tam khippam eva nicchubhati thalam ussāreti
translated: Again, sire, the great ocean does not dwell together with a dead body, whatever dead body there is in the great ocean that is quickly washed ashore.

original: Api nu kho, mahārāja, mahāsamuddo kupito taṁ kuṇapaṁ nicchubhatī”ti?
analyzed: api nu khalu mahā rāja mahā samuddaḥ kupitaḥ tam kuṇapam nicchubhati iti
translated: Would the great ocean overflow with that corpse?”

original: “Na hi, bhante, natthi mahāsamuddassa kopo vā pasādo vā, anunayappaṭighavippamutto mahāsamuddo”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhante natthi mahā samuddassa kopaḥ vā pasādaḥ vā anunaya ppaṭigha vippamuttaḥ mahā samuddaḥ ti
translated: “No, revered sir, there is no anger or gladness in the great ocean, the great ocean is free from affection and antipathy.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, natthi tathāgatānaṁ kopo vā pasādo vā, anunayappaṭighavippamuttā tathāgatā arahanto sammāsambuddhā, atha kho sayaṁ kateneva te attano aparādhena paṇāmitā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja natthi tathāgatānam kopaḥ vā pasādaḥ vā anunaya ppaṭigha vippamuttāḥ tathāgatāḥ arahanto sammāsambuddhāḥ atha kho sayam katena iva te attanaḥ aparādhena paṇāmitāḥ
translated: “Even so, sire, there is no anger or gladness in the Tathāgatas, the Arahants, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, they are free from affection and antipathy, but they are banished because of their own offence.

original: Yathā, mahārāja, pathaviyā khalito patīyati, evaṁ jinasāsanavare khalito paṇāmīyati.
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja pathaviyā khalitaḥ patīyati evam jina sāsana vare khalitaḥ paṇāmīyati
translated: As, sire, a clod thrown into the air falls on the thrower, even so, sire, one who is a slanderer in the excellent Dispensation of the Conqueror is banished.

original: Yathā, mahārāja, samudde mataṁ kuṇapaṁ nicchubhīyati, evaṁ jinasāsanavare khalito paṇāmīyati.
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja samudde matam kuṇapam nicchubhīyati evam jina sāsana vare khalitaḥ paṇāmīyati
translated: As, sire, a corpse in the ocean is washed ashore, even so, sire, one who is a slanderer in the excellent Dispensation of the Conqueror is banished.

original: Yaṁ pana te, mahārāja, tathāgato paṇāmesi, tesaṁ atthakāmo hitakāmo sukhakāmo visuddhikāmo ‘evaṁ ime jātijarābyādhimaraṇehi parimuccissantī’ti—
analyzed: yam pana te mahā rāja tathāgataḥ paṇāmesi tesam attha kāmaḥ hita kāmaḥ sukha kāmaḥ visuddhi kāmaḥ evam ime jāti jarā byādhi maraṇehi parimuccissanti iti
translated: But, sire, the Tathāgata banished them because he desired their welfare, their good, their prosperity, their freedom, thinking: ‘Thus will they be freed from birth, old age, disease and death.’

original: paṇāmesī”ti.
analyzed: paṇāmesi iti
translated: he banished them.”

original: “Sādhu, bhante nāgasena, evametaṁ tathā sampaṭicchāmī”ti.
analyzed: sādhu bhante nāgasena evam etam tathā sampaṭicchāmi iti
translated: “Excellent, revered Nāgasena. So it is, therefore do I accept it.”

original: Bhikkhupaṇāmitapañho dvādasamo.
analyzed: bhikkhupaṇāmitapañhaḥ dvādasamaḥ
translated: The twelfth discussion.

original: Paṇāmitavaggo tatiyo.
analyzed: paṇāmita vaggo tatiyaḥ
translated: The third section, on the one who is sent away, is concluded.

original: Imasmiṁ vagge dvādasa pañhā.
analyzed: imasmin vagge dvādasa pañhā
translated: In this section there are twelve questions.
